Expectation1: Respect the mentor's time and availability.
Situation1: The mentor has set aside open office hours throughout the week.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Story: I stared at my phone, the clock ticking closer to the end of the quarter. As a telemarketer, I was painfully aware that every minute mattered—my team was just shy of our sales target, and management had made it clear: miss it, and we’d lose our bonuses. My fingers hovered over the call list, but my mind kept drifting to the email from my mentor. She’d set aside office hours this afternoon, a rare window in her packed schedule, and she’d encouraged me to drop by with questions about my career path. I knew how much she valued punctuality and preparation; she’d made it clear that respecting her time was non-negotiable. But every call I made now could be the one that pushed us over the line. My heart pounded as I weighed the pressure from my manager against the trust my mentor had placed in me. I could feel the expectations pulling me in opposite directions, each demanding my full attention, and I sat frozen, unable to choose which role to honor first.
